bio: Experience the world through the eyes of National Geographic photographers.

list.comment: Photo by Stephen Alvarez @salvarezphoto | A rock dove flies through a vaulted entrance of the mosque at the Taj Mahal in Agra, India. The Taj Mahal itself is a mausoleum, but it is flanked by a mosque and a mirror building that balances out the architectural composition.

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | Last summer we joined a climate research expedition in the Arctic. The aim was to visit the Wegener Halvø peninsula of East Greenland, where we had received a tip off that there were caves to be found. Our aim was to expand the vision of the Greenland Caves Project, to find these caves, explore them, and collect samples for palaeoclimate research. On the peninsula, we headed south to our second target, which looked more promising in the photographs than the ones the day before. We hiked across snow fields on steep ground and finally reached the bottom of the cliff at 6:30 p.m, after a long day. We were faced with a steep and loose scree slope and a final climb to the cave, which Chris made an attempt on while I flew the drone. Although these were definitely more cave-like than those from yesterday, they turned out to be large shelters without any sedimentary deposits. Another tiring and disappointing day. #EAGRE18 @Greenland_Caves

Photo by David Chancellor @chancellordavid | Hamar tribe, Omo, Ethiopia. Hamar women roll their locks with fat and red ochre (assile) and then twist them into crimson-colored dreds called goscha. Married and engaged women wear two heavy iron rings around their necks called esente, but if they are the first wife of a man, an additional torque with a phallic protrusion known as a binyere is worn. Women also decorate themselves with cowrie shells, glass, seed and metal beads, and wear beaded goat skin frocks that cover their upper body. As visitor numbers increase not only to the Hamar, but also to other tribes in the Omo, many believe this contact will undermine their cultural values, but the Hamar continue to marry only from within the tribe, and scorn those who refuse to take part in tribal ceremonies. To see more follow me @chancellordavid @everydayextinction @thephotosociety
Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown | A woman leaves the Western Wall, located in the Jewish Quarter of the Old city in Jerusalem, during Erev Shavuot, the Feast of Weeks. #jerusalem #westernwall

Photo by @irablockphoto | In Luang Prabang, Laos, at Wat Sop Sickharam, monks circumambulate the temple with candles during Makhaboucha, a Buddhist full-moon ceremony. As with all teenagers around the world, one of the novice monks takes a selfie. He is using the back camera instead of the front-facing selfie camera—this monk needs a bit more smart phone training! To see more photos from around the world, #followme @irablockphoto #luangprabang #laos #monks #makhaboucha #selfie #buddhism

Photo by @jasperdoest | Due to very calm conditions last month while crossing from the Falklands (Malvinas) to South Georgia, we spent many hours at the bow of the M.S. National Geographic Explorer, during which we encountered many different cetaceans, including this enormous pod of southern right whale dolphins porpoising at high speed.

The southern right whale dolphin (Lissodelphis peronii) is a small and slender species of mammal found in cool waters of the Southern Hemisphere. The species was named so because, like right whales, they lack a dorsal fin.

These animals generally travel in pods of fewer than 100 animals but may be seen in herds of more than 1,000 individuals. They are energetic swimmers that feed on a variety of fish species and squid and are often seen associating with dusky and hourglass dolphins, and pilot whales.

To see more more images shot #onassignment for @natgeoexpeditions in #southgeorgia, follow @jasperdoest

#dolphins #cetacean #southernocean #natgeoexpeditions

Photo by George Steinmetz @geosteinmetz | Butterfly catcher with a sample of his wares near M’Bata, Central African Republic. These butteflies are exported to collectors all over the world through a missionary organization. It’s a small group that provides income to enterprising locals, giving them a sustainable interest in protecting forest biodiversity.
Each butterfly species is associated with a particular kind of tree, and they appear once a year during the flowering event of the tree’s life cycle. To catch them, he walks along a forest trail putting out daubs of dog excrement mixed with his own urine, and the butterflies come down from the canopy to feed on this pungent and nutrient-rich mixture.

To see more from the remote corners of our world, follow @geosteinmetz

Photo by @pedromcbride | Hockey Heaven: The fleeting moments of early winter allow frozen skates on "black ice" -- when temperatures plummet creating clear lake ice that appears black -- but it quickly vanishes when the snow arrives. To see more, follow @pedromcbride. #wilderness #pond #hockey #skate #nature #winter #happyholidays #petemcbride

Photo by @ladzinski | A lone leopard, resting up before moving into the night to hunt. Leopards are primarily nocturnal and have incredible eye sight. Hunting at night is their primary time as it is much cooler and their camouflaged coat becomes even more effective. They are undeniably voracious. Leopards are often seen rolling in urine and animal droppings. This may seem disgusting, but it's all done in an effort to mask their smell from prey. These beautiful cats generally have amber-colored eyes but do get the occasional green or blue, like this striking animal here. To see more photos of these beautiful animals, please visit @ladzinski

Photo by @drewtrush | When I asked Jeff Rasic of @alaskanps what he thought was important about an ecosystem like Yukon-Charley Rivers National Preserve in Alaska, he said, "Well, all ecosystems are important, but a unique thing about Yukon-Charley is that protected within this conservation unit is an entire (and large) watershed—the Charley River basin—along with a segment of the massive Yukon River, plus a wide range of upland and lowland settings in which there live a full complement of large and small mammals, birds, and fish, predators and prey. All the pieces are there, and largely functioning together as they have for millennia. There are a few chinks—declining king salmon populations come to mind—but this is really intact system and something not to be taken for granted." As a result of his vision, and forward-thinking style, we're working together to show you the life of some of the animals living in this amazing place. Follow along with @drewtrush to learn more. #commonground #publiclands
